title: Are GMOs good or bad?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the controversy surrounding GMOs in food and agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of genetic engineering in medical applications

options.label: B
options.text: The potential for GMOs to mix with traditional crops and introduce unwanted characteristics

options.label: C
options.text: The debate over the ethics of genetic modification

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of understanding about the science behind GMOs

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between selective breeding and genetic engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Selective breeding is more precise than genetic engineering

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic engineering eliminates the factor of luck in breeding

options.label: C
options.text: Selective breeding is only used for plants, while genetic engineering is used for animals

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic engineering is a slower process than selective breeding

multiple-choice.question: What are "Terminator seeds" and why were they not implemented?

options.label: A
options.text: Seeds that produce sterile plants, requiring farmers to buy new seeds every year, but were not implemented due to technical difficulties

options.label: B
options.text: Seeds that produce more resilient plants, but were not implemented due to lack of funding

options.label: C
options.text: Seeds that produce sterile plants, requiring farmers to buy new seeds every year, but were not implemented due to public outcry

options.label: D
options.text: Seeds that produce genetically modified plants, but were not implemented due to regulatory issues

multiple-choice.question: What is the conclusion of over 30 years of studies on the safety of GMOs for human consumption?

options.label: A
options.text: GMOs are more risky than non-GMOs

options.label: B
options.text: GMOs are equally as safe as non-GMOs

options.label: D
options.text: The safety of GMOs is still unknown

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of BT crops, and how do they work?

options.label: A
options.text: BT crops are engineered to produce a pesticide that kills specific insect pests, using a gene borrowed from the bacterium Bacillus Thuringiensis

options.label: B
options.text: BT crops are engineered to be resistant to certain weed killers

options.label: C
options.text: BT crops are engineered to produce more nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: BT crops are engineered to be more resilient to climate change

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criticism of the use of GMOs in modern agriculture?

options.label: B
options.text: The business practices of huge corporations that control the food supply

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a positive application of GMOs in agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of GMOs to produce more pesticides

options.label: B
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh that reduced insecticide use by over 80%

options.label: C
options.text: The use of GMOs to produce more resilient crops

options.label: D
options.text: The use of GMOs to produce more nutrients

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future application of GMOs in addressing climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: Engineering plants to be more resilient to climate change

options.label: D
options.text: Engineering plants to collect nitrogen from the air

multiple-choice.question: According to the UN, what is the estimated increase in food production needed by 2050?
What is the potential benefit of using GMOs to intensify farming instead of expanding it?

title: How did teeth evolve? - Peter S. Ungar

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason behind the impressive strength of teeth?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of only one layer of enamel

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of two layers: a hard external cap of enamel and a tougher layer of dentin

options.label: C
options.text: The absence of organic fibers in teeth

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of only odontoblasts that secrete dentin

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between hardness and toughness in the context of teeth?

options.label: A
options.text: Hardness refers to the ability to resist a crack from spreading, while toughness refers to the ability to resist a crack from starting

options.label: B
options.text: Hardness refers to the ability to resist a crack from starting, while toughness refers to the ability to resist a crack from spreading

options.label: C
options.text: Hardness and toughness are interchangeable terms

options.label: D
options.text: Hardness refers to the ability to grind food, while toughness refers to the ability to withstand breakage

multiple-choice.question: Which cells are responsible for secreting enamel and dentin in teeth?

options.label: A
options.text: Ameloblasts secrete dentin, while odontoblasts secrete enamel

options.label: B
options.text: Ameloblasts secrete enamel, while odontoblasts secrete dentin

options.label: C
options.text: Only ameloblasts secrete both enamel and dentin

options.label: D
options.text: Only odontoblasts secrete both enamel and dentin

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the ameloblasts once they finish forming the enamel layer?

options.label: A
options.text: They continue to secrete enamel throughout life

options.label: B
options.text: They move inward and become odontoblasts

options.label: C
options.text: They slough off when they hit the surface

options.label: D
options.text: They become dormant and can be reactivated

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate diameter of the long, thin strands of enamel produced by ameloblasts?

options.label: A
options.text: Odontoblasts secrete enamel, while ameloblasts secrete dentin

options.label: B
options.text: Odontoblasts secrete dentin throughout life, while ameloblasts only secrete enamel once

options.label: C
options.text: Odontoblasts and ameloblasts have the same function

options.label: D
options.text: Odontoblasts only secrete dentin once, while ameloblasts secrete enamel throughout life

options.label: D

title: The myth of Oisín and the land of eternal youth - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical outcome for a protagonist in the Irish genre of myth known as Eachtraí?

options.label: A
options.text: The protagonist returns home in triumph.

options.label: B
options.text: The protagonist undergoes great change and becomes immortal.

options.label: C
options.text: The protagonist's journey ends in a point of no return.

options.label: D
options.text: The protagonist becomes a legendary hero.

multiple-choice.question: Who is Oisín's father in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The immortal king of Tír na nÓg.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the immortal princess who falls in love with Oisín?

options.label: C
options.text: The Land of the Tuatha Dé Danann.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the land of Tír na nÓg?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a land of eternal darkness.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a land of eternal war.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a land of youth, where time stands still.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a land of ancient wisdom.

multiple-choice.question: Why does Oisín decide to leave Tír na nÓg?

options.label: A
options.text: He is bored with the luxurious life.

options.label: B
options.text: He misses his friends and family in Ireland.

options.label: C
options.text: He wants to explore the world beyond Tír na nÓg.

options.label: D
options.text: He is forced to leave by Niamh's family.

multiple-choice.question: What warning does Niamh give to Oisín before he leaves Tír na nÓg?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: He is transported back to Tír na nÓg.

options.label: C
options.text: He is recognized as a hero by the people.

options.label: D
options.text: He ages irreversibly and becomes an old man.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: She is sitting on a throne, ruling Tír na nÓg.

options.label: D
options.text: She is carried upon the distant waves by a white horse, still hoping for Oisín's return.

title: How does the immune system work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the immune system in the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: To break down food into nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: To safeguard against infection, illness, and disease

multiple-choice.question: Where do defensive white blood cells, also known as leukocytes, originate in the human body?

What are the molecular traces on the surface of pathogens and other foreign substances called?
Which type of leukocytes trigger the immune response by sending macrophages and dendritic cells into the blood?

options.label: C
options.text: To latch onto antigens and destroy invading cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a high temperature during an immune response?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To attract phagocytes to the affected area

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to develop long-term immunity

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of colds that a healthy immune system can successfully fight off over the course of a lifetime?
What type of diseases trick the immune system into attacking the body's own perfectly healthy cells?

title: Why should you read Charles Dickens? - Iseult Gillespie

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: There was no difference in the time it took to offer help

options.text: They are more likely to be in a hurry

options.label: A
